The word 'bacillus' (plural 'bacilli') may be used to describe any rod-shaped
bacterium, and such bacilli are found in many different taxonomic groups of
bacteria. However, the name [[Bacillus]], capitalized and italicized, refers to
a specific genus of bacteria. The name Bacilli, capitalized but not italicized,
can also refer to a more specific taxonomic class of bacteria that includes two
orders, one of which contains the genus Bacillus.

Bacilli are usually solitary, but can combine to form diplobacilli,
streptobacilli, and
palisades. [http://www2.nemcc.edu/bkirk/Template%201/MICROCHAPTER4NOTES.htm
CHAPTER 4 FUNCTIONAL ANATOMY OF PROKARYOTIC AND EUKARYOTIC CELLS ].

There is no connection between the shape of a bacterium and its colors in the
Gram staining. MacConkey agar can be used to distinguish among Gram negative
bacilli such as [[Escherichia coli|E. coli]] and salmonella.
